How are ratings calculated?
To calculate the overall star rating and percentage breakdown by star, we dont use a simple average. Instead, our system considers things like how recent a review is and if the reviewer bought the item on Amazon. It also analyzes reviews to verify trustworthiness.

Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2019
Verified Purchase
The dark-skinned family with afro hair looks like their dog? I purchased this book for a class that I teach but will be sending it back. Two stars for an effort towards inclusivity but I would never recommend a book that essentially says that people with dark skin and afro look like dogs.

None
5.0 out of 5 stars Toddler approved!
Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2017
Verified Purchase
My 2-year-old LOVES this book. He has asked me to read "Families book" multiple times every night since we received. it. He loves to "awooo" when we get to the noisy family page and laughs out loud at the clean and messy pigs. Ours is a single-parent family. I wanted to start introducing the idea of diverse family structures in a way that would be understandable and reassuring to a toddler. This book worked perfectly.

For those folks who are complaining that it includes two-mom and two-dad families, please deal with your bigotry. Regardless of whatever archaic views you hold on marriage equality, children in those families are entitled to dignity and a sense of self-worth that comes from pride in one's family. That's the ultimate message of this book.

evie23
5.0 out of 5 stars Yes, same sex parents do make up a normal family unit.
Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2016
Verified Purchase
One of Todd Parr's BEST books. These days there are many different types of families... single parent, step parents, relatives raising other peoples kids, same sex parents etc... and whether you agree with all these different family units or just some of them is your own right.. BUT it doesn't change the fact that not everyone believes or lives the way you think is the right way. And you children WILL be exposed to many different types of kids and their families in their daily lives... keeping them in the dark only leaves your child confused and uneducated. Also narrow minded. So to those complaining thay this book exposes young kids to same sex couples and therefore forces you to explain the birds and bees... well maybe if you weren't trying to hide equality from your kids and explained it to them, even if your explanation is that you believe it's wrong, then maybe they wouldn't be so shocked when they meet a classmate with 2 moms or 2 dads. It's a different world and it keeps changing... our kids are going to have to learn to accept eachother. Don't be your child's first bully... and more so, don't teach your child to be someone else's childs first bully. Ignorance leads to violence. Remember that.

D'Arcy
5.0 out of 5 stars Teaches diversity appreciation -- and opposites!
Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2016
Verified Purchase
We love Todd Parr's books and this is one of his best. I love that the book shows my son that families come in all kinds of varieties -- but no matter what, families love each other. It's a great book for teaching him an acceptance of and appreciation for diversity (diversity of family types but also of individual people). The book has the added bonus of teaching opposites as family types are shown in contrast with an opposite family type (families that all look alike vs. ones of different colors, loud vs. quiet families, etc.). I also LOVE that it normalizes families with gay parents. My son loves hearing about the families and seeing the bright, fun artwork.

Was this review helpful for you? If so, please click the "Yes" button below. If not, feel free to let me know why and I'll do my best to improve it. :)

CuriousMom
5.0 out of 5 stars Great for kids and parents.
Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2014
Verified Purchase
My 3-year old and I both love this book. At first I worried that it would be too simple for his age but the concepts are something we can talk about as we read. It's good for a quick 'last book' before lights out or as a discussion book on families. My lil guy has picked it out to read almost every night since we received it. I'd strongly recommend it for other families who want to educate their kids on the many types of families or just have a fun book to read.

Addresses but is not limited to, step-siblings, adoption, different color family members, different dietary restrictions in a family, big families, single parent family, same sex parent families and more.

K. Hirsch
5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent book on showing all different types of families!
Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2017
Verified Purchase
This is a perfect book to start reading to a very young child about different family types. Illustrations are bright and colorful with families represented in purple, yellow, orange, green, blue...and using people as well as animals, like ducks, pigs, dogs, cats, and goldfish. Minimal words with straight forward meanings, e.g., "Some families have one parent instead of two". Some of the illustrations have glasses, some are bald, some have straight hair, some have curly hair...it is a fantastic book. And the message at the end rocks: "There are lots of different ways to be a family. Your family is special no matter what kind it is." And it includes all family types - big, small, interracial, adoption, single parent, same sex parents, etc. Age group is young, 1 to 5 I would say. Perfect for me and my daughter - thanks author Todd!

Aimee
5.0 out of 5 stars Fun book for explaining what can be a complex topic.
Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2016
Verified Purchase
We ordered this book to demonstrate to our daughter that there are all different types of families. We are an alternative family make up (same sex married couple) and were looking for a fun and upbeat way to explain that there are all different kinds of families and as long as everyone is loved and their needs are met those family types are all ok. This book did a good job of doing that. It also prompted a bunch of thoughtful questions from my toddler about all of the other family types and colors so really got her thinking. The book has colorful imagery and fun writing to keep kids attention. All in all we highly recommend this book.
